subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Unicode proposal again.
msgSnippet: ... And there are reasons why, which don t apply to a proposed disunification of QS from Shavian, as far as I can see so far. ... I don t know what that is. Or
messageBody:
At 21:06 +0100 2007-05-29, amd64_hacker wrote:
>True, but it isn't just glyph shapes either - it's function also.
>The French 'u' and English 'u' are both part of the Latin alphabet.
>Cyrillic Capital Letter A and Latin Capital Letter A are all but
>identical in appearance but have different code points.

And there are reasons why, which don't apply to a proposed
disunification of QS from Shavian, as far as I can see so far.

>One of the really, really nice side effects of
>Quikscript/Shavian/phonic-alphabets-in-general is that they don't
>need
>as much work to create soundex/metaphone type functions for.

I don't know what that is. Or those are. But that is a higher-level
protocol which deals with an underlying encoding, I take it.

>The difficult bit, converting letters to sounds, has already been done
>for you and at that point it basically boils down to an edit distance
>search.

Yes, well, I remember making the Talking Moose speak Irish. Talking
Moose orthography is an orthography that can be read by some software
which reads character sequences. It was never designed for Irish. You
could get it to work though.

>If we work purely on the appearance we lose the phonic information and a
>lot of ease of use.

"Phonic"?

>We can consolidate Shavian and Quikscript characters which are identical
>but we shouldn't throw away all that extra information/functionality for
>the sake of a few code points.

The Universal Character Set is not really concerned about "a few code
points". But the encoding of QS must be in accordance with The Way We
Actually Do Things. Please take note that John Cowan and I are here
because we want to help you. If we disagree with disunifying QS from
Shavian it's because that's what's going to get you the characters
that you need.

>Especially considering the main use of soundex/metaphone is in spell
>checkers which would probably be even more useful in Quikscript than
>they are in Latin.

Could you explain what this means?
--
Michael Everson * http://www.evertype.com
